desc: ATRX, a tumor suppressor involved in transcriptional regulation, is infrequently mutated in cancer.

ATRX (alpha thalassemia/mental retardation syndrome X-linked), a gene on the X chromosome (PMID: 20110566), encodes a protein associated with a severe form of X-linked syndromal mental retardation often associated with alpha thalassemia (ATRX) syndrome (PMID: 8968741). ATRX is a member of the SWI1/SNF2 family of helicase/adenosine triphosphatases (ATPase) that are involved in chromatin remodeling (PMID: 20110566, 17609377). Structurally, ATRX consists of a C-terminal helicase/ATPase domain and an N-terminal ATRX-DNMT3-DNMT3L (ADD) domain that is a PHD-like zinc finger (PMID: 17609377). The ADD domain is involved in chromatin binding and DNA binding (PMID: 17609377). ATRX is involved in the incorporation of histone H3.3 during telomere replication (PMID: 20110566). Loss of function or loss of ATRX expression is strongly correlated with an alternate lengthening of telomeres (ALT) phenotype in tumors (PMID: 21719641). Mutations in ATRX have been associated with chromosomal instability and therefore play a role in oncogenesis (PMID: 24148618).
articles/0/title: ATRX encodes a novel member of the SNF2 family of proteins: mutations point to a common mechanism underlying the ATR-X syndrome.

articles/3/title: Altered telomeres in tumors with ATRX and DAXX mutations.
articles/4/title: Loss of DAXX and ATRX are associated with chromosome instability and reduced survival of patients with pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
